posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: The textcore device is based on a CM5, and I'm curious if the WPIlib suite, including DS communication and actuator heartbeat, can run on a Raspberry Pi for lab training scenarios. Instead of using the SystemCore offering, we mainly need an Raspberry Pi with a CAN hat for our requirements. Would that setup work?
The SystemCore is an expansion board. Even though running the full SystemCore OS/Image on it may solve most issues, there will still be problems like "DEVICE NOT FOUND."

Still, the ROMI should probably work, though I haven‚Äôt used it in ages so I might be wrong.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: During subsystem development, each sub-team uses its own RoboRio to drive their mechanism. During the fall, our rookie cohort builds up several simple robots, each with a RoboRio. I'm aware of the ROMI and XRP, that's not what I'm interested in. Regarding ‚Äúdevice not found,‚Äù that‚Äôs what the HAL is for, no?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
The HAL is for handling device-related tasks, such as communication and coordination, which simplifies operations rather than complicating them. While the primary HAL provides essential functionalities, creating an alternate HAL tailored for specific devices adds complexity due to the need for specialized configurations and additional resources. This process involves developing a custom Pi kernel, which requires significant effort in terms of both time and technical expertise.

We do not have ownership of the heartbeat functionality or the DS Driver Station comm code; these aspects are determined externally and fall outside our control. The actuator heartbeat operates as a kernel module, necessitating the compilation of a custom Pi kernel to integrate it into our system.

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Testing SPI-CAN communication between an MCP2515 and an Arduino via a Raspberry Pi showed successful operation at 500 kbps, but performance degraded at higher speeds. Initially relying on bit manipulation due to difficulties installing the Python spidev library and failing MOSI-MISO loopback tests suggested potential hardware compatibility issues. My limited expertise may explain these challenges, though further investigation is needed. Please excuse the repetition; I aim to provide constructive feedback.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
I'm currently using bit banging because I couldn't get the Python spidev library installed. On the Raspberry Pi side? You should use the mcp2515 kernel driver and socketcan instead. On a Raspberry Pi you can enable this by applying one of the device tree overlays for use with the mcp2515. Even using that driver, it may struggle to reliably receive all messages at high bitrates on a bus with high utilization- this is due to the fact that the mcp2515 can only hold 2 received messages at a time, and if the host processor (the pi, in this case) hasn't read the message before more messages arrive, the incoming messages will be dropped. The pi receives an interrupt request every time a message is received, but most of the interrupt routine implemented in the Linux driver is executed in a threaded (non-hard IRQ) context, so depending on system configuration and load, it can still be overwhelmed. These are really designed to be used with a bare metal microcontroller that can service interrupts quickly.

re: CAN hats, these are COTS things. If you're wanting to match the functionality of the SystemCore CAN interfaces, this hat will work well. It uses the same CAN controllers as SystemCore (MCP2518FD), which have good driver support in Linux and don't suffer the issue I mentioned above as they are able to queue quite a few messages onboard.

[Amazon link]

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: 2-Channel Isolated CAN Bus FD Expansion HAT for Raspberry Pi, with MCP2518FD CAN Controller and MCP2562FD CAN Transceiver, Supports Original CAN2.0 and CAN FD Protocols, Multi Protection Circuits : Electronics

The software theoretically could check if it‚Äôs running on a computer module or not, but I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs much of a point to that and it‚Äôs not difficult to work around from what I remember.

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: Thank you, yes it is on the raspberry side. I edited the Systemcore boot config to enable spi and I can see that MCP2515 was initialized after reboot but clock reports as 4MHz. Also "sudo ip link set can0 type can bitrate 1000000" returns invalid argument. "sudo ip link set can0 type can bitrate 500000" sets the bitrate to 500kbps successfully but I believe I need 1Mbit/s for FRC CAN communication. I actually bought that 2-channel CanFD Hat but it won‚Äôt arrive for another week. I got a few 2515s someone gave me so I am just trying to get them working.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
The text is: "The text is:
BABER:

I edited the Systemcore boot config to enable spi

I‚Äôd recommend not doing this with the systemcore image, at least while you‚Äôre trying to get it working. If you must, I‚Äôd recommend disabling the systemcore CAN interface overlays.

BABER:

I can see that MCP2515 was initialized after reboot but clock reports as 4MHz. Also ‚Äúsudo ip link set can0 type can bitrate 1000000‚Äù returns invalid argument. ‚Äúsudo ip link set can0 type can bitrate 500000‚Äù sets the bitrate to 500kbps successfully but I believe I need 1Mbit/s for FRC CAN communication.

You‚Äôre currently telling the driver that the controller is using an 8MHz external oscillator. Is this what you actually have attached? If it‚Äôs not, you‚Äôll need to set the correct frequency in the overlay configuration in config.txt.

Linux won‚Äôt let you set the bitrate to 1Mbps because that bitrate isn‚Äôt achievable with the MCP2515 using an 8Mhz oscillator. On the MCP2515, 1 time quanta is 2 cycles of the external oscillator (which is why the clock is reported as 4Mhz). To achieve 1Mbps reliably on this chip you‚Äôll need an oscillator with a frequency of at least 16MHz.

Cleaned Up Text: BEBER mentions editing the Systemcore boot config to enable SPI and advises against using the systemcore image while troubleshooting. BEBER recommends disabling the CAN interface overlays. Additionally, BEBER describes encountering issues with the MCP2515 initialization, noting a 4MHz clock post-reboot and difficulties setting the bitrate to 1Mbit/s for FRC and CAN communication via IP Link. BEBER explains that attempting to set the bitrate to 1000000 resulted in an invalid argument, though setting it to 500000 worked. BEBR emphasizes the need for an 8MHz external oscillator, noting Linux limitations in achieving a stable 1Mbps bitrate with the MCP2515. BEBR concludes that at least a 16MHz oscillator is required for reliable 1Mbps CAN communication on the MCP2515.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Wpilib will require all five buses to exist, which is likely why nothing is loaded. Additionally, five buses are needed for the heartbeat. We expect all the hardware that exists on system core. If you don't have all of it, things won't work properly.
